THE NEWS-LETTER.
Vol. VII.

MARCH 19, 1903.

No. 11.

A MODERN LAND OF PROMISE.
1Z, PIMA.] I NE NT New York man said recently to a seeker for advice, in words
somewhat similar to Horace Greeley's famous aphroism, "Young man,
go to Mexico. There the opportunity is ripe for work of all kinds, and
offers the best field I know of at present."
Mexico has been called "the Egypt of the New World," and travelers can
indeed see a decided similarity between this earliest seat of American civilization
and that other cradle of the world's culture along the valley of the Nile. The
same dry, healthy climate attracts visitors to both lands, the same diversity of
arid desert and tropical vegetation is to be found, and the ancient temples and
pyramids of the Pharaohs find their counterpart only a little less in antiquity and
size in this historic part of the New World. In fact, the remains of the Aztec
and earlier civilizations in Mexico show such a decided similarity to the characteristics of the early Egyptians, that students have been led to consider seriously
the question of the Semitic origin of the American races, and a late writer has
eyen advanced the theory of America as the source of Asiatic culture.
Most people in the more northern section of the United States have erroneons ideas .of Mexico, both as a country and as a people. The country they
regard as a land of base prairie and primitive conditions, and the people as an
tintutored race of aborigines. Both ideas are far from fact. The land is ex1 remelv diversified, ranging from the luxurious . foliage of the tropics to mountains of splendid timber and fine ranch land, with considerable areas of sagebrush plain, yet less dreary in aspect probably, than the miles and miles of barren
deserts in Arizona and other districts of the Southland. Crops grow fast in
Mexico,. often three or more in a year; the climate is advantageous for cattle
and sheep raising, and the country needs only care to make it flow with milk
and honey.
Those who say there are no antiquities in America, have only to visit Mexico
to find themselves in the midst of as ancient scenes and thrilling spots of romance
as are to be found in any part of modern Europe. In the capital of Montezuma
was found by Cones and his men, says a writer, "a civilization superior to that
which they had left behind them in Spain," with a 'finely organized government,
a splendid fighting force, and flourishing in all the arts which accompany a refined and cultivated people. The only blot which historians find upon the .Aztec
people, was the barbarous regime of the priesthood, and yet this, considering all
things, was no ,worse than the horrors of the Holy Inquisition, then in the height
of its unholy practices in Spain. And before the Aztec Empire exerted its sway

monument or a building. In this city of Durango, which
as a frontier post against the unconquered natives of the North-west, whole rows
of dwellings, erected at that time, are still occupied. and the city theatre has been
;n active use for three hundred years. Compared with buildings in the United
States, which spring up like mushrooms in a night, and in a few years are torn
down to make place for others, the public edifices of Mexico date back to a
remote antiquity.
But if Mexico can be compared in its physical characteristics to ancient
Egypt, there is possibly an equally strong likeness to that land which the Israelites
looked to as promised to their father Abraham. Mexico is to present day Americans, a veritable land of promise, and throngs are crossing over daily to occupy
the soil and to sit in the high places.
American capital is pouring into Mexico at an enormous rate. Railroads
are being extended and improved, municipal lighting and power plants and water
works are being constructed, improved mining and smelting methods are being
introduced ; rubber, sugar and coffee plantations are being rapidly developed, and
all this is being largely done by Americans with American capital. It is estimated
that the American capital invested in Mexico at present, amounts to about half a
billion dollars. Presidelit Diaz, one of the greatest statesmen of this or any age,
has extended a cordial welcome to American capitalists, engineers and merchants,
and has offered them exceptional facilities for developing the opportunities
which they have secured. All nations are represented in the search for the gold
of which Mexico has been the mythical storehouse ever since the days of Spanish
discovery, and the City of Mexico is one of the most cosmopolitan cities in the
Mexico is in the transitional stage which the United States passed
world.
through about twenty years ago, when electricity began to supplant horse-power
and steam, and with rapid transit came improved methods in all kinds of manufacturing and distributing machinery. • The steel skeleton building is taking its
place beside the century-old adobe house ; the latest mining machinery is supplanting the crude appliances that have been used ever since the mines were first
opened by the Spaniards ; the electric car and the electric light are well established ; and all the railroad companies have men out surveying lines to new points,
which will thus be given at once a tremendous impetus to growth. The greater
part of all this activity is in the hands of Americans, who thus find opportunity to
reproduce in a new country the same movements that took place in the Opening
up of the Western lands shortly after the Civil War.
There is no reason why the opening up of Mexico should not result in a
prosperity similar to that of the great Western States of the Union. There are

many inqucements for settlers, not the least of them being a generous and equable
climate, where the snows of winter and the terrific heat of mid-summer are equally
unknown. The only draw-back to the greatest prosperity is the unstableness of
the currency, but this question is at this 'very time being considered by a monetary
commission, called for that very purpose. One of the greatest booms is expected
in Mexican real estate, which, it is prophesied, will be worth in gold in a few years
what it now brings in depreciated silver.
The outlook for American engineers, physicians, dentists, chemists, machinists, and trained men of any kind, seems bright. Americans are very cordially
received by the Mexican people. In some cases the Americans are, however, no
more able to penetrate the rigidity 'of the social usages in Mexico than are other
foreigners, but wherever the strictness of Spanish convention is relaxed, the
Americans stand as the most favored people. In many places the American
residents who are educated and refined, are received freely in the homes of the
wealthiest Mexican families, and invited to the balls and exclusive entertainments
of the fashionable Mexican set. In some instances American young men are
given liberty to call upon Mexican ladies at their homes.
This privilege,
largely denied by Mexican convention to even the beaux of their own race, who
are forced,to conduct a courtship at long range, shows how great is the friendship of our neighbors south of the Rio Grande.

DR. SIDNEY LEE ON ELIZABETHAN LITERATURE.
N Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday and Friday of last week, Sidney Lee, Litt.
D., of London. England, delivered a series of extremely interesting lectures
on the general subject,"Foreign Influences on Elizabethan Literature."
The lectures were given on the Caroline Donovan foundation, and were largely attended by both University men and the general public, and Dr. Lee spoke in a manner so attractive as to instruct and entertain all.
Dr. Lee is widely known as the editor of the "Dictionary of National Biography," and is the author of a "Life of William Shakespeare," which has supplanted all other works on the same subject, and a life of Queen Victoria, the
latter recently published. He came to Baltimore after delivering a series of lectures on "Famous Men of the Elizabethan Age," in Boston and Philadelphia.
While here he was the guest of Dr. Osler.
"The Comparative Study of Elizabethan Literature," was the subject of Dr.
Lee's first lecture. With a few appropriate remarks President Remsen introduced the lecturer, who spoke for an hour in the voice of a man who is intensely
interested and well-grounded in his subject. He developed the idea that whereever we may turn in the great poets of the Elizabethan Era, we shall always find
in their works the influences of some foreign masterpieces. "The Elizabethan
literature," said Dr. Lee, "is part of the European intellectual movement, we call
the Renaissance. Everywhere the Western literature developed from that of

0

THE NEWS LETTER.
Greece and Rome ; hence, to properly appreciate Elizabethan literature, we must
have some knowledge of Greek and Latin poetry."
Dr. Lee spoke on "Italian Influence" in his second lecture. According to
him, although the works of Dante were little known in England, it was to the
Italian writers, both great and small, that the Elizabethans made resort. In
speaking of the pastoral drama, Dr. Lee said: "The pastoral drama owed its form,
its ideas, and, in fact, everything to contemporary Italian drama. The influence
of Dante was not great, nor was that of Petrarch so pronounced on the subsequent literature of Western Europe, as was that of 'Boccaccio. We can estimate
to some extent the influence of .Boccaccio on modern Western Europe, when we
remember that he is the ancestor of the modern novel."
The third topic was "French Influence." Dr. Lee said the French literature
had exerted a greater influence upon English literature than that of any other nation. He showed how Italian poetry had influenced the French poets, and, how
these in turn, had passed this influence on to the English. "The influence of
French poetry on Elizabethan literature was probably most conspicuous in the
vast sonnet literature which was produced in Elizabethan England towards the
end of the sixteenth century." Dr. Lee also spoke at some length on the influence of French prose upon English prose, especially the writings of Montaigne.
"His works were translated into English," said Dr. Lee, "and they became exceptionally popular. Shakespeare put a whole passage from Montaigne in his
'Tempest.'"
The concluding lecture was upon "Foreign Influence upon Shakespeare."
Dr. Lee said that the Latin poetry was especially well-known to Shakespeare, and
that it had a great influence upon his poetry. Ovid was a great favorite. Whataid the poet obtained from Greek poetry was derived from English translations. "Despite this foreign influence." Dr. Lee declared, "the literature of that
day was a national one."

Morning. Prayers every
and helpful.

These services are pleasant

On Tuesday afternoon, March 31st, Mr. J. M. Rice, Secretary of the Baltimore and Ohio Branch of the Baltimore Association, will speak to us about the
Railroad work. Mr. Rice is having splendid success in his work with railroad
men. He will have something very interesting to tell us about an important department of Christian work, which is being greatly appreciated by all large railroad corporations.
The State Convention, which was held in Baltimore March 1;th, 7th and .8th,
proved to he a success for the vkiting delegates. The home association did not
derive as much benefit as possible, because the members did not avail themselves
of the opportunities. Those of us who did attend derived much of pleasure and
interest from it.
The program was good, especially on Friday evening at Brown Memorial
Church, when Mr. rI illar told of the wonderful advance in Army and Navy work
in the last five years. The address of Dr. Woelfkins of Brooklyn, on "Temptation," was an exceptionally strong one.
The Student Conferences interested us most. They were conducted by M r.
A. B. Williams, Jr., Yale, '98, Intercollegiate Secretary for the East and Canada.
Most of the important lines of Association work in our colleges were under discussion. The One on Friday afternoon was held at the Central Association, and
on Saturday afternoon in Levering Hall. The colleges from Maryland and Delaware were well represented. St. John's sent twenty-seven men from Annapolis,
and Delaware College had ten.
The luncheons on Friday and Saturday were also very interesting. Tables
were set for the delegates in one of the large class rooms of the Central. The decorations were Hopkins Northfield streamers and shield.
The one on Saturday especially appealed to the college delegations, when one
from each college was called upon to state why his was the best institution. There
was considerable good natured bantering and bragging done, but proved very
amusing as well as instructive to those of us who knew very little of any but
Hopkins.
Almost every man who attended any of the sessions was more impressed
with the importance of the Association work, and decided to render better service.

S its leading article for this issue the Ni.:ws 1,1mi.:1( prints an interesting
account of that modern land of promise, Mexico. To the majority of the
undergraduates Mr. Boyer is no stranger, and all will be pleased to learn
of his success in Mexico. His glowing account of that country will no doubt
arouse the interest of the men who are about to leave the university and know not
whither to turn their steps. To them Mr. Boyers article should appeal with more
than passing- interest. It it true that a. man of ability can make opportunities, no
matter where he may be, but it is also true that in a locality where the period of
rapid growth has already passed, opportunities are not to be found as readily as
in a new country. Mexico is just such a new country. It has the internal resources, and now it needs men, men with ideas, to develop those resources. To
be sure, an American is hampered at the start by not knowing the language, but
soon this can be overcome by being thrown in contact with the natives. Such a
draw-back should not deter anyone from going to Mexico who feels that the future
of the country is really as bright as it has been painted. The adoption of a stable
currency will strengthen :\ I exico's relations with other nations, and the present
activity is only the dawn of that new era.

THE NEWS LETTER.
N LESS something is done to relieve the present stringency of the editorial
pocket-book, the News 14KVITY intends to seek out some beneficent philanthropist, and urge him to provide a fund upon which impecunious young
I en may draw when the photographer presents his bill. The mania for taking photographs is expensive, and we regret to say that it seems to be upon the increase.
This burden falls with more than usual weight upon the members of the Senior
Class. Not an organization, team, board, or committee but feels that its duty has
not been faithfully performed unless a group picture has been taken. The picture seems to give to the board an air of authority and a seal of legality which
otherwise might 1...)e lacking. We deny that there is any desire upon the part of
the young men to hand down the group picture to posterity, in order that future
ages may know what giants there were in the good old days when Hopkins consisted of several buildings in the heart of the city, and a future which was nothing
but promising. No, indeed. However, the group picture has a duty to perform
aside from filling the coffers of heartless, grasping, inordinate photographers. It
serves as a constant reminder that, in some respects, the life of our uncivilized
ancestors was not without its compensations. No doubt Adam and Ev,-; chortled
with glee when they ascertained that there were no camera fiends in the vicinity,
representing the Garden of Eden year book for the year Naughty-naught, eager
to take a group picture of the first lady president of the Dress Reform League,
and her other and better half. When our ancestors exchanged their bear-skin
clothing and their cave dwelling for the spike-tailed coat and the modern apartment house they really made a change for the better. But if they got the best of
the bargain when they made an, exchange for the group picture, we shudder to
think what they gave up when they made the trade.

HE Hopkins athletic games to be held at the Fifth regiment Armory on the
28th of this month, bid fair to be the most important ever held in this cit v.
Before everything else they have been arranged with a view of giving the
spectators an interesting evening's entertainment. Georgetown will be represented
by Duffy, Holland, and other. crack runners. Pennsylvania will send men. The
relay races will be important features. So far all the efforts which have been
made to make the meet an example of what good, successful athletes really are
have met with unqualified success. The regimental committee having the Armory
building in charge, have offered courteously to allow short spikes to be used on
this one occasion. This is . a highly complimentary concession, and one which
is thoroughly appreciated by Hopkins men. II makes possible the presence of
several famous runners who otherwise would not compete.
According to the entry blanks, the handicaps have been restricted to reasonable distances by the games committee, thus insuring to the scratch man a
chance of making his presence felt. Another feature will be the special scratch
events. These are far more satisfactory than the usual handicap 'races, and will
give an twortunity of judging of the real ability of the several contestants.

HULLABALOO CLUB FEED.
HE wish of the poet, "Make me a child again just for to-night," was amply
fulfilled when the Hullabaloo Club gave a "Feed" in the Trophy Room
last Monday night. The list of impromptu stunts was a long one, and was
enjoyed to the utmost by the spectators, if not by the participants themselves.
The feature of the evening was a race between Mr. Strayer and Mr. Amitien,
which resulted in Mr. Strayer being victorious, .as Mr. Ammen never quite 'finished the lap. Mr. Strayer was so wrought up over his victory, or else lost his
head, that he ran an extra lap for good measure, paced by Mr. Plaggemeyer. He
was so overcome by these exertions that for the remainder of the evening he did
nothing but blow and puff.
A tug of war was another startling swent. On one side was ranged all the
brains of the class, and on the other side was all the brawn and muscle. Tt is needless to say that the brawn and muscle came out the winner. :lint the defeated part
of the class will have their revenge on Saturday night.
The evening closed with a game known in the vernacular as ''cuckoo bases."
Mr. Plaggemeyer obligingly consented to be "it." His first prize was Mr. Smith,
who was unmercifully thumped as he beat a hasty retreat to the base. And so
it went. Could all outsider have seen that crowd of red-faced, coatless, breathless,
happy, shouting, nondescript band of boys, he never would have guessed that the
"most potent, teverend and grave seniors" were taking a night off and thoroughly
enjoying themselves.

THE GEORGETOWN GAMES.
Z H E Georgetown games are now a thing of the past. In every particular .
these games were thoroughly satisfactory to all concerned, and too much
cannot be said to the credit of those who had them in charge, for the masterly manner in which they were run off. The list of entries was unusually large.
Such institutions as Pennsylvania, Cornell, Columbia, Harvard', Princeton and
Johns Hopkins were represented, as well as other schools, athletic clubs and associations, thereby bringing together the fastest men in the business. Consequently
every event was hotly contested, and a victory valued accordingly. The showing
made by Baltimore men was very creditable. Hopkins, for her part, had her
greatest success in the Relay Race with Villa Nova. Clarence Stone, in his first
appearance on the team, started the good work by a lead of 3 yards at the end
of his run. Captain Hoffman was passed by his opponent, but finally recovered
his loss and finished with 12 yards to the good. Freese in his turn increased this
. distance, and England ended the race in great style. Besides this race, Freese
won a close second in the 50 yard hurdle. Pessagno also showed up well in the
50 yard dash, finishing second in the semi-finals. The absence of Helmholtz and
Tootle in the dashes was deeply felt. All of our men who went over to see the
games felt fully repaid for their trouble, and have no unfavorable criticism to make.

OUTDOOR LACROSSE.
On last Saturday afternoon the lacrosse squad practiced at Druid Hill Park
for the first time this season, and since then they have been able to get in several
days of good work out of doors. The men showed the need of out-door exercise,
as they were pretty well done up by the unwonted exertion.
The playing was fast, and for that reason could not be kept up for any considerable time. The absence of some of the older men, who could not find it convenient to go out at this stage of the game, was seriously felt. It is expected that in a
few (lays all of them will be out, including the men from the medical school.

The "Inter-collegiate News" says:— "The annual report of President Eliot
of Harvard University contains for the first time a reference to athletics at
Harvard.
"President Eliot calls attention to the interesting fact that at least 2,000 of
the 3,500 students in the Cambridge department of the university take part in
some outdoor sport. He notes that changes in football rules have been followed
by an increase rather than a decrease in injuries, and says that 'Under the existing- rules the game tends to become slower and less visible in its details, and
therefore less interesting. Moreover, the ethics of the game, which are the imperfect ethics of war, do not improve. The martial axiom—attack the enemy's weakest point—inevitably leads to the deliberate onslaught on the cripple or the convalescent in the opposing line ; and the habitual violation of rules, if peimlties be
escaped, is regarded by many as merely amusing.'"

Tired, are you? Well, my dearie,
Such is life; we all are weary
Sometimes. Come and cuddle closer,
Put your head upon my shoulder,—
Golden head that twice five summers
Scarce have shed their suns upon.
Love you? Look into the fire,
See that flame, that ever higher
Seems to leap than all its brothers,
No beginning has, nor ending;
There you see my love for you, boy,
Comes from nowhere, nowhere goes to;
Ever living, all embracing.
Lower downward look; see lacing
In and out the burning embers
Darts a breath, a pale blue phantom,
Makes each glowing coal grow brighter,
Now bedulls their flaming throbbing;
Thus you play upon my soul, boy,
Make it gleam, then dim its radiance,
Lifting me to heights sublimest,
Plunging me in deep despair.
There were loves before your coming?
Called them loves, but now I see that
They were just the first few letters
Of the alphabet of loving.
Now, my boy, Love's volume open
Lies before me, and there spelling
Out each word, with you, my teacher,
Every day new pleasures showing
In the reading of Love's lore.
Odd now, is't not, that a boy like
You, can twirl around his finger
Me, whose years are more than treble
His? So, tell me by what power
You've compelled me to your service?
Cannot? Listen, I will tell you:
Look into the mirror yonder;
See the hair, than spun gold brighter,
See the eyes, with depths of blueness
Stole out of Heaven's ether;
See the nose more straight and whiter
Than the fairest beam of Luna ;

See the lips so red, that rubies
E'en do blush a shade more redder
Lest those same red bps should put them
l'nto shame and spoil their lustre.
Look again. See, white as ivory,
Gleams a neck and marble bosom
Pure and virgin as the heart that
Throbs beneath it and the Soul that
Lurks there somewhere. I can tell you
Nothing further. Boy, I love you
Just because you are yourself.
You have crept into my being;
Nestled there as on my shoulder
Nestles now your curly head ; and
Every movement, every throbbing-,
Each pulsation of your heart, wakes
In my soul a deep emotion
E'en the gods could never measure.
No, I think there's nothing further
When a soul, completely. merging
in another soul, there loses
All sensation, each emotion,
Save those by its fellow wakened.
Drifting over Love's vast. ocean
Past the shores of pain and pleasure
Past the islands of regretting,
Naught exists, save thou and I, Boy ;
In eternity, past, future,
And beyond it, all is silence.
Sleepy ? Well, good night then, deari;
Happy dreams dance through your slumbers.

SOME FACTS ABOUT THE ELEVATOR
1. That it is safer for Freshmen to abstain from the luxury entirely.
2. That if he be so heavily burdened by his hard lot that his tender limbs
refuse to climb the pathway to knowledge, let him recede into the farthest corner
of the lift, and there, with head uncovered, and eyes fixed meekly on the floor,
wait until some of his more elevated brethren stop the car.
3. That it is healthier to climb the stairs than to ride, when the elevator is
not going.
4. That it is useless to press the button of the elevator not in use.
5. That the man with the black skull cap should not be crowded, he becomes peevish.
6. That if the elevator contain six or more juniors, no others are admitted.

A MODERN LAND OF PROMISE.
1Z, PIMA.] I NE NT New York man said recently to a seeker for advice, in words
somewhat similar to Horace Greeley's famous aphroism, "Young man,
go to Mexico. There the opportunity is ripe for work of all kinds, and
offers the best field I know of at present."
Mexico has been called "the Egypt of the New World," and travelers can
indeed see a decided similarity between this earliest seat of American civilization
and that other cradle of the world's culture along the valley of the Nile. The
same dry, healthy climate attracts visitors to both lands, the same diversity of
arid desert and tropical vegetation is to be found, and the ancient temples and
pyramids of the Pharaohs find their counterpart only a little less in antiquity and
size in this historic part of the New World. In fact, the remains of the Aztec
and earlier civilizations in Mexico show such a decided similarity to the characteristics of the early Egyptians, that students have been led to consider seriously
the question of the Semitic origin of the American races, and a late writer has
eyen advanced the theory of America as the source of Asiatic culture.
Most people in the more northern section of the United States have erroneons ideas .of Mexico, both as a country and as a people. The country they
regard as a land of base prairie and primitive conditions, and the people as an
tintutored race of aborigines. Both ideas are far from fact. The land is ex1 remelv diversified, ranging from the luxurious . foliage of the tropics to mountains of splendid timber and fine ranch land, with considerable areas of sagebrush plain, yet less dreary in aspect probably, than the miles and miles of barren
deserts in Arizona and other districts of the Southland. Crops grow fast in
Mexico,. often three or more in a year; the climate is advantageous for cattle
and sheep raising, and the country needs only care to make it flow with milk
and honey.
Those who say there are no antiquities in America, have only to visit Mexico
to find themselves in the midst of as ancient scenes and thrilling spots of romance
as are to be found in any part of modern Europe. In the capital of Montezuma
was found by Cones and his men, says a writer, "a civilization superior to that
which they had left behind them in Spain," with a 'finely organized government,
a splendid fighting force, and flourishing in all the arts which accompany a refined and cultivated people. The only blot which historians find upon the .Aztec
people, was the barbarous regime of the priesthood, and yet this, considering all
things, was no ,worse than the horrors of the Holy Inquisition, then in the height
of its unholy practices in Spain. And before the Aztec Empire exerted its sway

monument or a building. In this city of Durango, which
as a frontier post against the unconquered natives of the North-west, whole rows
of dwellings, erected at that time, are still occupied. and the city theatre has been
;n active use for three hundred years. Compared with buildings in the United
States, which spring up like mushrooms in a night, and in a few years are torn
down to make place for others, the public edifices of Mexico date back to a
remote antiquity.
But if Mexico can be compared in its physical characteristics to ancient
Egypt, there is possibly an equally strong likeness to that land which the Israelites
looked to as promised to their father Abraham. Mexico is to present day Americans, a veritable land of promise, and throngs are crossing over daily to occupy
the soil and to sit in the high places.
American capital is pouring into Mexico at an enormous rate. Railroads
are being extended and improved, municipal lighting and power plants and water
works are being constructed, improved mining and smelting methods are being
introduced ; rubber, sugar and coffee plantations are being rapidly developed, and
all this is being largely done by Americans with American capital. It is estimated
that the American capital invested in Mexico at present, amounts to about half a
billion dollars. Presidelit Diaz, one of the greatest statesmen of this or any age,
has extended a cordial welcome to American capitalists, engineers and merchants,
and has offered them exceptional facilities for developing the opportunities
which they have secured. All nations are represented in the search for the gold
of which Mexico has been the mythical storehouse ever since the days of Spanish
discovery, and the City of Mexico is one of the most cosmopolitan cities in the
Mexico is in the transitional stage which the United States passed
world.
through about twenty years ago, when electricity began to supplant horse-power
and steam, and with rapid transit came improved methods in all kinds of manufacturing and distributing machinery. • The steel skeleton building is taking its
place beside the century-old adobe house ; the latest mining machinery is supplanting the crude appliances that have been used ever since the mines were first
opened by the Spaniards ; the electric car and the electric light are well established ; and all the railroad companies have men out surveying lines to new points,
which will thus be given at once a tremendous impetus to growth. The greater
part of all this activity is in the hands of Americans, who thus find opportunity to
reproduce in a new country the same movements that took place in the Opening
up of the Western lands shortly after the Civil War.
There is no reason why the opening up of Mexico should not result in a
prosperity similar to that of the great Western States of the Union. There are

many inqucements for settlers, not the least of them being a generous and equable
climate, where the snows of winter and the terrific heat of mid-summer are equally
unknown. The only draw-back to the greatest prosperity is the unstableness of
the currency, but this question is at this 'very time being considered by a monetary
commission, called for that very purpose. One of the greatest booms is expected
in Mexican real estate, which, it is prophesied, will be worth in gold in a few years
what it now brings in depreciated silver.
The outlook for American engineers, physicians, dentists, chemists, machinists, and trained men of any kind, seems bright. Americans are very cordially
received by the Mexican people. In some cases the Americans are, however, no
more able to penetrate the rigidity 'of the social usages in Mexico than are other
foreigners, but wherever the strictness of Spanish convention is relaxed, the
Americans stand as the most favored people. In many places the American
residents who are educated and refined, are received freely in the homes of the
wealthiest Mexican families, and invited to the balls and exclusive entertainments
of the fashionable Mexican set. In some instances American young men are
given liberty to call upon Mexican ladies at their homes.
This privilege,
largely denied by Mexican convention to even the beaux of their own race, who
are forced,to conduct a courtship at long range, shows how great is the friendship of our neighbors south of the Rio Grande.

DR. SIDNEY LEE ON ELIZABETHAN LITERATURE.
N Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday and Friday of last week, Sidney Lee, Litt.
D., of London. England, delivered a series of extremely interesting lectures
on the general subject,"Foreign Influences on Elizabethan Literature."
The lectures were given on the Caroline Donovan foundation, and were largely attended by both University men and the general public, and Dr. Lee spoke in a manner so attractive as to instruct and entertain all.
Dr. Lee is widely known as the editor of the "Dictionary of National Biography," and is the author of a "Life of William Shakespeare," which has supplanted all other works on the same subject, and a life of Queen Victoria, the
latter recently published. He came to Baltimore after delivering a series of lectures on "Famous Men of the Elizabethan Age," in Boston and Philadelphia.
While here he was the guest of Dr. Osler.
"The Comparative Study of Elizabethan Literature," was the subject of Dr.
Lee's first lecture. With a few appropriate remarks President Remsen introduced the lecturer, who spoke for an hour in the voice of a man who is intensely
interested and well-grounded in his subject. He developed the idea that whereever we may turn in the great poets of the Elizabethan Era, we shall always find
in their works the influences of some foreign masterpieces. "The Elizabethan
literature," said Dr. Lee, "is part of the European intellectual movement, we call
the Renaissance. Everywhere the Western literature developed from that of

0

THE NEWS LETTER.
Greece and Rome ; hence, to properly appreciate Elizabethan literature, we must
have some knowledge of Greek and Latin poetry."
Dr. Lee spoke on "Italian Influence" in his second lecture. According to
him, although the works of Dante were little known in England, it was to the
Italian writers, both great and small, that the Elizabethans made resort. In
speaking of the pastoral drama, Dr. Lee said: "The pastoral drama owed its form,
its ideas, and, in fact, everything to contemporary Italian drama. The influence
of Dante was not great, nor was that of Petrarch so pronounced on the subsequent literature of Western Europe, as was that of 'Boccaccio. We can estimate
to some extent the influence of .Boccaccio on modern Western Europe, when we
remember that he is the ancestor of the modern novel."
The third topic was "French Influence." Dr. Lee said the French literature
had exerted a greater influence upon English literature than that of any other nation. He showed how Italian poetry had influenced the French poets, and, how
these in turn, had passed this influence on to the English. "The influence of
French poetry on Elizabethan literature was probably most conspicuous in the
vast sonnet literature which was produced in Elizabethan England towards the
end of the sixteenth century." Dr. Lee also spoke at some length on the influence of French prose upon English prose, especially the writings of Montaigne.
"His works were translated into English," said Dr. Lee, "and they became exceptionally popular. Shakespeare put a whole passage from Montaigne in his
'Tempest.'"
The concluding lecture was upon "Foreign Influence upon Shakespeare."
Dr. Lee said that the Latin poetry was especially well-known to Shakespeare, and
that it had a great influence upon his poetry. Ovid was a great favorite. Whataid the poet obtained from Greek poetry was derived from English translations. "Despite this foreign influence." Dr. Lee declared, "the literature of that
day was a national one."

On Tuesday afternoon, March 31st, Mr. J. M. Rice, Secretary of the Baltimore and Ohio Branch of the Baltimore Association, will speak to us about the
Railroad work. Mr. Rice is having splendid success in his work with railroad
men. He will have something very interesting to tell us about an important department of Christian work, which is being greatly appreciated by all large railroad corporations.
The State Convention, which was held in Baltimore March 1;th, 7th and .8th,
proved to he a success for the vkiting delegates. The home association did not
derive as much benefit as possible, because the members did not avail themselves
of the opportunities. Those of us who did attend derived much of pleasure and
interest from it.
The program was good, especially on Friday evening at Brown Memorial
Church, when Mr. rI illar told of the wonderful advance in Army and Navy work
in the last five years. The address of Dr. Woelfkins of Brooklyn, on "Temptation," was an exceptionally strong one.
The Student Conferences interested us most. They were conducted by M r.
A. B. Williams, Jr., Yale, '98, Intercollegiate Secretary for the East and Canada.
Most of the important lines of Association work in our colleges were under discussion. The One on Friday afternoon was held at the Central Association, and
on Saturday afternoon in Levering Hall. The colleges from Maryland and Delaware were well represented. St. John's sent twenty-seven men from Annapolis,
and Delaware College had ten.
The luncheons on Friday and Saturday were also very interesting. Tables
were set for the delegates in one of the large class rooms of the Central. The decorations were Hopkins Northfield streamers and shield.
The one on Saturday especially appealed to the college delegations, when one
from each college was called upon to state why his was the best institution. There
was considerable good natured bantering and bragging done, but proved very
amusing as well as instructive to those of us who knew very little of any but
Hopkins.
Almost every man who attended any of the sessions was more impressed
with the importance of the Association work, and decided to render better service.

S its leading article for this issue the Ni.:ws 1,1mi.:1( prints an interesting
account of that modern land of promise, Mexico. To the majority of the
undergraduates Mr. Boyer is no stranger, and all will be pleased to learn
of his success in Mexico. His glowing account of that country will no doubt
arouse the interest of the men who are about to leave the university and know not
whither to turn their steps. To them Mr. Boyers article should appeal with more
than passing- interest. It it true that a. man of ability can make opportunities, no
matter where he may be, but it is also true that in a locality where the period of
rapid growth has already passed, opportunities are not to be found as readily as
in a new country. Mexico is just such a new country. It has the internal resources, and now it needs men, men with ideas, to develop those resources. To
be sure, an American is hampered at the start by not knowing the language, but
soon this can be overcome by being thrown in contact with the natives. Such a
draw-back should not deter anyone from going to Mexico who feels that the future
of the country is really as bright as it has been painted. The adoption of a stable
currency will strengthen :\ I exico's relations with other nations, and the present
activity is only the dawn of that new era.

THE NEWS LETTER.
N LESS something is done to relieve the present stringency of the editorial
pocket-book, the News 14KVITY intends to seek out some beneficent philanthropist, and urge him to provide a fund upon which impecunious young
I en may draw when the photographer presents his bill. The mania for taking photographs is expensive, and we regret to say that it seems to be upon the increase.
This burden falls with more than usual weight upon the members of the Senior
Class. Not an organization, team, board, or committee but feels that its duty has
not been faithfully performed unless a group picture has been taken. The picture seems to give to the board an air of authority and a seal of legality which
otherwise might 1...)e lacking. We deny that there is any desire upon the part of
the young men to hand down the group picture to posterity, in order that future
ages may know what giants there were in the good old days when Hopkins consisted of several buildings in the heart of the city, and a future which was nothing
but promising. No, indeed. However, the group picture has a duty to perform
aside from filling the coffers of heartless, grasping, inordinate photographers. It
serves as a constant reminder that, in some respects, the life of our uncivilized
ancestors was not without its compensations. No doubt Adam and Ev,-; chortled
with glee when they ascertained that there were no camera fiends in the vicinity,
representing the Garden of Eden year book for the year Naughty-naught, eager
to take a group picture of the first lady president of the Dress Reform League,
and her other and better half. When our ancestors exchanged their bear-skin
clothing and their cave dwelling for the spike-tailed coat and the modern apartment house they really made a change for the better. But if they got the best of
the bargain when they made an, exchange for the group picture, we shudder to
think what they gave up when they made the trade.

HE Hopkins athletic games to be held at the Fifth regiment Armory on the
28th of this month, bid fair to be the most important ever held in this cit v.
Before everything else they have been arranged with a view of giving the
spectators an interesting evening's entertainment. Georgetown will be represented
by Duffy, Holland, and other. crack runners. Pennsylvania will send men. The
relay races will be important features. So far all the efforts which have been
made to make the meet an example of what good, successful athletes really are
have met with unqualified success. The regimental committee having the Armory
building in charge, have offered courteously to allow short spikes to be used on
this one occasion. This is . a highly complimentary concession, and one which
is thoroughly appreciated by Hopkins men. II makes possible the presence of
several famous runners who otherwise would not compete.
According to the entry blanks, the handicaps have been restricted to reasonable distances by the games committee, thus insuring to the scratch man a
chance of making his presence felt. Another feature will be the special scratch
events. These are far more satisfactory than the usual handicap 'races, and will
give an twortunity of judging of the real ability of the several contestants.

HULLABALOO CLUB FEED.
HE wish of the poet, "Make me a child again just for to-night," was amply
fulfilled when the Hullabaloo Club gave a "Feed" in the Trophy Room
last Monday night. The list of impromptu stunts was a long one, and was
enjoyed to the utmost by the spectators, if not by the participants themselves.
The feature of the evening was a race between Mr. Strayer and Mr. Amitien,
which resulted in Mr. Strayer being victorious, .as Mr. Ammen never quite 'finished the lap. Mr. Strayer was so wrought up over his victory, or else lost his
head, that he ran an extra lap for good measure, paced by Mr. Plaggemeyer. He
was so overcome by these exertions that for the remainder of the evening he did
nothing but blow and puff.
A tug of war was another startling swent. On one side was ranged all the
brains of the class, and on the other side was all the brawn and muscle. Tt is needless to say that the brawn and muscle came out the winner. :lint the defeated part
of the class will have their revenge on Saturday night.
The evening closed with a game known in the vernacular as ''cuckoo bases."
Mr. Plaggemeyer obligingly consented to be "it." His first prize was Mr. Smith,
who was unmercifully thumped as he beat a hasty retreat to the base. And so
it went. Could all outsider have seen that crowd of red-faced, coatless, breathless,
happy, shouting, nondescript band of boys, he never would have guessed that the
"most potent, teverend and grave seniors" were taking a night off and thoroughly
enjoying themselves.

THE GEORGETOWN GAMES.
Z H E Georgetown games are now a thing of the past. In every particular .
these games were thoroughly satisfactory to all concerned, and too much
cannot be said to the credit of those who had them in charge, for the masterly manner in which they were run off. The list of entries was unusually large.
Such institutions as Pennsylvania, Cornell, Columbia, Harvard', Princeton and
Johns Hopkins were represented, as well as other schools, athletic clubs and associations, thereby bringing together the fastest men in the business. Consequently
every event was hotly contested, and a victory valued accordingly. The showing
made by Baltimore men was very creditable. Hopkins, for her part, had her
greatest success in the Relay Race with Villa Nova. Clarence Stone, in his first
appearance on the team, started the good work by a lead of 3 yards at the end
of his run. Captain Hoffman was passed by his opponent, but finally recovered
his loss and finished with 12 yards to the good. Freese in his turn increased this
. distance, and England ended the race in great style. Besides this race, Freese
won a close second in the 50 yard hurdle. Pessagno also showed up well in the
50 yard dash, finishing second in the semi-finals. The absence of Helmholtz and
Tootle in the dashes was deeply felt. All of our men who went over to see the
games felt fully repaid for their trouble, and have no unfavorable criticism to make.

OUTDOOR LACROSSE.
On last Saturday afternoon the lacrosse squad practiced at Druid Hill Park
for the first time this season, and since then they have been able to get in several
days of good work out of doors. The men showed the need of out-door exercise,
as they were pretty well done up by the unwonted exertion.
The playing was fast, and for that reason could not be kept up for any considerable time. The absence of some of the older men, who could not find it convenient to go out at this stage of the game, was seriously felt. It is expected that in a
few (lays all of them will be out, including the men from the medical school.

Manager Addison has received a letter from the management of the Universit v of Thronto team accepting the sixth of June as the date of the game between
the two teams in this city. The. Toronto men expect to begin their out-door work
this week.
The February number of the Intercollegiate News contains excellent portraits
of i\ Ii-. Ronald T. Abercrombie, president of the Athletic Association, and official
coach of the Lacrosse Team, and M r. Henry P. Straus, captain of the Lacrosse
Team.
Our first game is scheduled for the fourth of April, with the University of
Pennsylvania, but as yet nothing has been heard from the Penn. management.
Some trouble has been encountered in securing grounds for the Baltimore
games. American League Park is the best place for the, games, but inasmuch as
the Eastern League schedule has not been arranged, it is impossible to secure the
grounds definitely for the lacrosse dates, as the two schedules may conflict.

The "Inter-collegiate News" says:— "The annual report of President Eliot
of Harvard University contains for the first time a reference to athletics at
Harvard.
"President Eliot calls attention to the interesting fact that at least 2,000 of
the 3,500 students in the Cambridge department of the university take part in
some outdoor sport. He notes that changes in football rules have been followed
by an increase rather than a decrease in injuries, and says that 'Under the existing- rules the game tends to become slower and less visible in its details, and
therefore less interesting. Moreover, the ethics of the game, which are the imperfect ethics of war, do not improve. The martial axiom—attack the enemy's weakest point—inevitably leads to the deliberate onslaught on the cripple or the convalescent in the opposing line ; and the habitual violation of rules, if peimlties be
escaped, is regarded by many as merely amusing.'"

Tired, are you? Well, my dearie,
Such is life; we all are weary
Sometimes. Come and cuddle closer,
Put your head upon my shoulder,—
Golden head that twice five summers
Scarce have shed their suns upon.
Love you? Look into the fire,
See that flame, that ever higher
Seems to leap than all its brothers,
No beginning has, nor ending;
There you see my love for you, boy,
Comes from nowhere, nowhere goes to;
Ever living, all embracing.
Lower downward look; see lacing
In and out the burning embers
Darts a breath, a pale blue phantom,
Makes each glowing coal grow brighter,
Now bedulls their flaming throbbing;
Thus you play upon my soul, boy,
Make it gleam, then dim its radiance,
Lifting me to heights sublimest,
Plunging me in deep despair.
There were loves before your coming?
Called them loves, but now I see that
They were just the first few letters
Of the alphabet of loving.
Now, my boy, Love's volume open
Lies before me, and there spelling
Out each word, with you, my teacher,
Every day new pleasures showing
In the reading of Love's lore.
Odd now, is't not, that a boy like
You, can twirl around his finger
Me, whose years are more than treble
His? So, tell me by what power
You've compelled me to your service?
Cannot? Listen, I will tell you:
Look into the mirror yonder;
See the hair, than spun gold brighter,
See the eyes, with depths of blueness
Stole out of Heaven's ether;
See the nose more straight and whiter
Than the fairest beam of Luna ;

Just because you are yourself.
You have crept into my being;
Nestled there as on my shoulder
Nestles now your curly head ; and
Every movement, every throbbing-,

In my soul a deep emotion

No, I think there's nothing further
When a soul, completely. merging
in another soul, there loses
All sensation, each emotion,
Save those by its fellow wakened.
Drifting over Love's vast. ocean
Past the shores of pain and pleasure
Past the islands of regretting,
Naught exists, save thou and I, Boy ;
In eternity, past, future,
And beyond it, all is silence.
Sleepy ? Well, good night then, deari;

SOME FACTS ABOUT THE ELEVATOR
1. That it is safer for Freshmen to abstain from the luxury entirely.
2. That if he be so heavily burdened by his hard lot that his tender limbs
refuse to climb the pathway to knowledge, let him recede into the farthest corner
of the lift, and there, with head uncovered, and eyes fixed meekly on the floor,
wait until some of his more elevated brethren stop the car.
3. That it is healthier to climb the stairs than to ride, when the elevator is
not going.
4. That it is useless to press the button of the elevator not in use.
5. That the man with the black skull cap should not be crowded, he becomes peevish.
6. That if the elevator contain six or more juniors, no others are admitted.
